question: What's that picture?
answer: This is me and my dad playing Battleship at my dad's apartment. Mick? My parents are divorced. But that's OK `cause the most important thing is to know that everybody loves each other.

question: So, who's that in that picture up on top?
answer: That's my fish, his name is Jaws and he's a really mean fish. My mommy is a Think Tank worker and she is really, really smart. She went to two colleges and has three computers. This is the day that my daddy says is the happiest day of his life.

question: Fran?
answer: You getting this yet?

question: Hey, I'm at Kevin's school. What's goin' on?
answer: I'm sorry, Brother. Riyadh. Many Dead.

question: Where exactly?
answer: The Al-Rahmah Western Housing Compound. Oil Company employees. Hit a company picnic.

question: How?
answer: Big. Broad daylight. Blew up a softball game. Kids, Brother.

question: Fran, I'm rollin' right now. Let me call you back Son, I gotta go to work.
answer: We're gonna do ceramics...

question: I gotta go to work...
answer: Who was that?

question: Big Fran -- you remember him?
answer: Uncle Fran? Put peanuts in his Coke so he could drink and eat all at the same time?

question: Where he's from in South Carolina that's called fine-dining, Bud.
answer: What happened?

question: Something bad. I love you.
answer: You gonna go see him?

question: No falsehoods, Sergeant Haytham. What was your involvement?
answer: Killing those I saw responsible.

question: So none could be questioned?
answer: I don't understand.

question: You were born and raised in Suweidi-
answer: -that is not a crime-

question: -it should be.
answer: It's not. I do not.

question: Your brother was killed fighting the Americans. True or false?
answer: I am not my brother.

question: Your brother--
answer: I am NOT my brother!

question: We found six more uniforms than you were assigned in your possession -- that is a crime
answer: Uniforms?

question: Truth!
answer: I sweat. I'll say it again because it is true. I need more uniforms because I must change during shifts...look at my shirts.

question: I am not interested in your sweat.
answer: -then look at my jackets. Please. Permanent stains...no matter how many times they're cleaned...

question: He's telling the truth. Look at me, Haytham. You saved lives today. I believe that. You served your country. I believe that.
answer: I love my country.

question: I believe that, Haytham...
answer: I love my country...

question: Everyone's terrified, so nothing moves. Paralysis. You and your team aren't going anywhere. And this meeting is just a circle- jerk, Ronnie Can you handle this? Keep your mouth shut when people way above you say things you'll hate?
answer: Yeah, sure. No problem.

question: What about Agent Mayes?
answer: Ask her.

question: I apologize if we're late-
answer: They were early.

question: You know Special Agent Fleury?
answer: I do.

question: This is agent Janet Mayes, she's one of our Arabic experts.
answer: OK. The latest.

question: OK. The latest.
answer: Two suicide bombers. Rumors they were dressed as Saudi Police. We believe this is the work of Saudi terrorist named Abu Hamza.

question: Go on.
answer: A Shooter crew served as distraction. After the initial attack there was a lull to allow Saudi Emergency Teams...and our own attaches...to collect. Then a secondary blast was triggered, aimed at those first responders. So they targeted families and rescuers with one attack. I think that's a clear signal that their definition of `Enemy' is expanding.

question: Let us never forget how cheap life is over there. Now...I have seven minutes before my next meeting, so who's talking first? You two digested the memo?
answer: As we are about Rex Burr.

question: It's all rock-solid logic.
answer: We would just like to be on record as saying we think we should go

question: That's not going to happen -so as we present this to the public, let's - as best we can - try to view this through an FBI Agent's eyes. And please let me know if there's anything else we can do for you.
answer: Sir, how would you imagine it looks viewed through an FBI agents eyes?

question: Pardon me?
answer: I'm interested in how you think this situation is viewed through our eyes.

question: It's some variation on vengeance... When one of your own is killed, Agents lose their analytical powers - kind of a greatest strength, greatest weakness thing...
answer: If I wanted vengeance, I'd have whispered `Rex Burr' into Ellis's ear right when we walked in. This isn't Terrorism, ma'am. It's just Serial Murder. To call this massacre an act of terrorism... that implies a specific political agenda. To me, these killings are so futile and unbalanced that they feel utterly sociopathic- more like Charles Manson than Osama Bin Laden...

question: If I wanted vengeance, I'd have whispered `Rex Burr' into Ellis's ear right when we walked in. This isn't Terrorism, ma'am. It's just Serial Murder. To call this massacre an act of terrorism... that implies a specific political agenda. To me, these killings are so futile and unbalanced that they feel utterly sociopathic- more like Charles Manson than Osama Bin Laden...
answer: Al Qaeda lost the first phase of this war, so a new, zero-sum phase has begun

question: When she says talented, she's not talking about the walking-bombs who can sneak past any and all security, nor the hi-jackers tough enough to take an airliner. We're talking about the Man who teaches them how...
answer: --the operational commander who organizes, trains, plans, encourages. That is who we're fighting.

question: I see the look in your eyes. That look is trouble
answer: It's not vengeance.

question: It ain't justice. It's stronger. We've all been there. I have. Vengeance is always dirty, Ronnie.
answer: I just can't sit this out. I can't watch this not get dealt with. Not again. Know what my high school football coach used to say to me?

question: What?
answer: "HIT SOMETHING." All night long, Coach Bailey would scream "HIT SOMETHING." Every play.

question: That's good coaching.
answer: I'm fixing to go hit something, boss. You with me?

question: How you gonna do it?
answer: The Saudis covet good PR as much as their Oil

question: What's your take?
answer: Looks like every overthrow in history

question: White House call you with a spin?
answer: You kidding? We don't talk since I broke the Vice President's guy cooking dirty intel on Iran. They hate me. What's up, Fleury?

question: How hard you gonna hit the Royal Family in your column tomorrow?
answer: With a sledgehammer.

question: With the bombings? Or other things...
answer: What's "other" than the bombings?

question: I know you're tracking Al Haramain.
answer: Is that what you want to talk about? Saudi officials making donations that end up... What? Blowing up trains in Paris? Buses in London?

question: Sometimes. Seems that just might happen. We got some other stuff
answer: Murder...Hookers...Houston? Can I take some notes?

question: I'm not saying that.
answer: Are you saying anything?

question: I need a favor.
answer: I don't do favors, Ronnie.

question: When it's real and it will be real... I'll come to you with what we have first. It's yours. Exclusive. You call Thamer at the Embassy. Tell him that the FBI is getting real close to laying out some major Saudi VIP indictments relating to newly uncovered charity financing out of a Boston investment firm. We're gonna freeze a lot of Saudi cash and roll out some major embarrassment.
answer: Can I mention Houston?

question: It's a free world, baby. Ask him to comment.
answer: He won't.

question: Tell him that I'm running the investigation. Tell him that I'm not the nicest kid on the block.
answer: That would be accurate.

question: I want fifteen minutes with him tonight.
answer: Wow. OK. And I get what?

question: I come to you first. No one else.
answer: What's really going on here, Ronnie? You going strong over Fran Manner?

question: I'm just trying to do my job, Elaine. That's it. Call Thamer.
answer: I'll see what I can do.

question: Get back in. Too many people we both know were at the bar. It's a pleasure to meet you, Your Highness.
answer: I had an interesting conversation with a reporter from the Post.

question: She can be a bit of an exaggerator... I'm sure things were somewhat over-stated. I see myself as friend of Saudi Arabia. I just need a little cooperation, that's all.
answer: What kind of cooperation??

question: Full cooperation
answer: Next month would be as soon as...

question: This goes one of two ways. First
answer: My family is not decaying-

question: And then we bring the hammer down hard as hell
answer: You have no proof of this.

question: We're getting there, Sir. And I haven't even brought up the two girls still missing out of Houston. This is big. It is real. And I know you only care so much about public American opinion, Sir. But the story will be covered... Big... And this ain't the Metro section. It's above the fold, just below the date. Words like these get syndicated to papers like the Omaha World-Herald, The Terrell Tribune -- You ever been to Terrell, Texas?
answer: What is your point?

question: Last I heard, 112 people lost their lives in your country. One of them was a good friend of mine. I want in and I want in immediately.
answer: Define "immediately."

question: We cannot allow 100 agents-
answer: -4. With a 25-man security detail-

question: -even 25 more armed Americans could spark rebellion-
answer: That's too bad.

question: Saudi Security. That's non negotiable. You cannot bring guns into the Kingdom.
answer: Men in Saudi Police uniforms are why we're talking now.

question: They would be hand picked.
answer: Whose hands?

question: What happened?
answer: You haven't heard about the attack?

question: I choose not to listen anymore. What happened to your face?
answer: An attack today.

question: What was Fran Manner to her?
answer: He taught her how to shoot, she taught him most everything else. Celebrated graduation at the IHOP in-town until some Townie called Janet something...Something not very nice. Townie didn't see Fran coming outta the Head. But he definitely felt Fran's uppercut shatter his jaw.

question: Fran didn't get bounced for that?
answer: SAC Fleury took care of him.

question: How?
answer: If I knew how I'd be SAC Sykes. I do know the post in Riyadh was part of the deal Fleury cut to save Fran's career.

question: Thanks for volunteering.
answer: Actually, I didn't volunteer.

question: Thanks anyway.
answer: We're going to Riyadh?

question: Nope.
answer: White House said yes?

question: Nope.
answer: Anybody said yes?

question: Not really.
answer: Are we bringing security?

question: Nope.
answer: This is going to suck so bad.

question: What's going on in there?
answer: I'm good.

question: Feels like you got a beast in there, Fleury.
answer: I'm good

question: "Good" is 6:00 am Sunday morning when your kid climbs into your bed, buries himself into you... sun's creeping through the windows - soft. Birds and wind-chimes... that's "good."
answer: I'm OK...You don't think I'm OK?

question: I think you're not entirely clear right now. That's OK, but you got to know that. You want to go - we go. I got you, but you got to check yourself.
answer: I'm checked.

question: OK. I'm just checking that you checked.
answer: How we doing? They gonna let us land? Good. Hunting... Big Game hunting. Heads on a swivel.

question: You have portable lights on-scene?
answer: Yes. But your team cannot work nights.

question: We only have seven days
answer: Five days. And you are not safe at night.

question: We're safe during the day?
answer: WATCH IT-SLOW!

question: Colonel, do you believe Abu Hamza was responsible for this attack?
answer: We don't know.

question: Were Saudi Police involved in the attack?
answer: We don't know that either.

question: Any word on what that third big blast was?
answer: Not yet.

question: Good afternoon, Sir.
answer: `Sunlight is indeed the most powerful disinfectant. In that spirit I come before this Judiciary Committee with a painful admission. Simply

question: Senators? Then I'd change `outmoded' to `outdated,' `echelons' to `ranks' and what in God's name is `contretemps?' These guys aren't the best and brightest-
answer: -never take the Lord's name in vain in this office-

question: -but you can say `Fucking?' You're going to the Senate Select Committee, but not to the President who appointed you. Why's that? I bet the President wasn't the audience you thought he'd be
answer: -you really want to bet?

question: They don't have fire codes. They don't have codes other than codes of war. They'll lock us in and dial up some kind of earth movers if they want to. You know that, Sykes. Dig a big hole and push us in. Fill it up and no one comes calling. You're in the jungle now, baby.
answer: You alright, girl?

question: Watch it, boy.
answer: Just asking...

question: Daddy?
answer: What you doing?

question: I'm talking to you. What are you doing right now, Daddy? Right now?
answer: I'm missing you.

question: Where are you?
answer: I'm in Saudi Arabia.

question: Did you see Big Fran?
answer: Yeah... I saw him...

question: Is he still tall?
answer: Yeah... Yeah...he's still tall.

question: Daddy? Are you still there?
answer: Yeah, buddy. I love you. Keep your eye on your mama. Be the man.

question: You, too Daddy.
answer: I'll call you tomorrow. I love you.

question: What did the Prince say?
answer: That there are more rules than just not working at night.

question: What rules?
answer: You are here as observers. Not investigators.

question: That's not accurate--
answer: --I need to make sure the sites are secure. Then you can begin observing.

question: I am sorry for the time. You won't need you gear.
answer: Of course we won't.

question: The remaining rules
answer: I would have thought your primary concern was investigating a crime.

question: --the bombers didn't wear a soldier's uniform. They wore mine.
answer: Who is in charge of the investigation then?

question: General Abdul-Malik. He's given us permission to walk through each crime-scene.
answer: To walk through? Are you kidding me?

question: I am not.
answer: Get him over here now and let's clarify this situation.

question: There is no lack of clarification.
answer: There sure as hell is! I don't know what kind of game you're playing but you got the wrong guy, Colonel Al-Ghazi! That was not the deal-

question: This is not a game show, Mr. Fleury! There are no deals made here. There is me telling you what you may or may not do and there is you doing it. You will be permitted to walk through the crime scenes. When we have determined that it is safe.
answer: How have you guys been doing with the witnesses?

question: So has Everyone else now.
answer: My girlfriends in Texas spend their combat pay on diamonds... I spent mine on a safe room.

question: Two nights back. Can you start one second before you knew anything was wrong?
answer: We didn't really see anything. Just hit the ground and hustled to the safe room. Closed our eyes and prayed. It was so fast. So loud.

question: Mr. Aaron Jackson?
answer: Get him away from me-

question: -easy, Sir. He's a friend to us-
answer: -I don't know either one a' you.

question: I'm Special Agent Ronald Fleury of the FBI. This is Colonel Al-Ghazi with the Saudi State Police-
answer: -the Police I just put my boys down for the first time in two days. I can't wake `em and sure as hell can't be gone if they stir on their own.

question: Can I come back?
answer: WHY?

question: Your boys... To ask about two nights ago.
answer: When my wife's jaw was shot off in front of our sons? My sons who sat with her while she bled to death? Couldn't speak because she didn't have the bottom of her face and I wasn't home and my baby boys are destroyed for life and my five year- old had a box of band-aids in his hand when I finally got home?

question: ...I won't pretend to know...
answer: Kill everyone that had something to do with this. Everyone related to them. Everyone who knew them. And all you'd be doing is their recruiting for them... It's an entire generation

question: Up the street, there was a wreck, did you see any-
answer: -notice how it wouldn't take a lot to disguise your friend as a Mexican? Think he couldn't handle crossing our deserts? Look around!

question: No -- from the tanks of this fire engine
answer: Hole is the case. See, there's "evidence" down in that hole. You understand evidence? Little things that are "clues." Clues can be very helpful to a fella when he's trying to solve a crime.

question: I understand that.
answer: Glad to hear it. So can we get in there?

question: The car was parked here?
answer: Yes.

question: Backed in?
answer: Yes.

question: Nobody's talking. Here, many people love Hamza - they think of him like Bin Laden. Like your Robin Hood. A man who thinks of something like this ...while maybe his family played around him... scares me more than I have words to express. Shaytan...
answer: Two big answers in two small minutes. Imagine if we had a couple days together. I'm sure the General is good guy...and I'm just as sure he's no Investigator. Let me help you.

question: We break now
answer: And I imagine that will run until sundown?

question: We're here.
answer: Big wall.

question: It's a big palace.
answer: How many Princes are there?

question: That's my most prolific Hunter. I'm trying to teach his friends there by example, but I fear it's something you're born with or not. Do you agree, Mr. Ronald? Innate or not at all?
answer: I do.

question: What have you seen so far of our Kingdom? -- and know I can arrange tours anywhere within our borders.
answer: I've seen that the man who planned the worst crime in your Kingdom's history is without a doubt Saudi... ..and that if you walk 300 kilometers from the compound, you will find a rooftop where the attacks were planned. I've seen that the person in this room "born with it" is right there... Everything I just said came from Colonel Al-Ghazi

question: They can have every shred of credit-
answer: -you see the slums on the way in?

question: Yeah.
answer: See that even though their homes are falling down, they had satellite dishes bolted on?

question: Yeah...
answer: Everyone already knows you're here. Credit? If the Saudis cracked this Cell while these servants were pouring coffee, Al-Jazeera still leads the story with your Team.

question: Have you been to the crime-scene?
answer: No-

question: -if you had, you'd see the evil work of real Talent. The kind that doesn't stop until it's forced.
answer: And the path to Hell is paved with good intentions.

question: You having fun?
answer: Beats hell outta visa-stamping. You're on an island. I hope you know how to get off.

question: By catching Abu Hamza.
answer: Then here's to you. Let's bet

question: ... every investigator on-scene by midnight, 50 more portable lights, three more pumps-
answer: Do me a favor and tell Janet that she and Damon Schmidt got a date when he gets back to the States.

question: The rules still stand. But tomorrow will be a new day. From now on, any evidence you find you hand over. I'm "all ears," Special Agent Fleury.
answer: We should start with the dead shooters.

question: They had no identification on them. Fingerprints and dental have come up empty.
answer: Can we photograph all three of them? Couple hundred copies each...

question: No problem.
answer: Good. If it's OK with you, I'd like to suggest we split up as follows...

question: I don't know any of them.
answer: I'm just wondering. That chair out side. Looks like it gets a lot of wear. Looks comfortable.

question: That my mom's chair.
answer: See, that's exactly what I was thinking. I'm guessing she spends a lot of time sitting outside?

question: All day.
answer: She must pretty much see it all. Right?

question: She does.
answer: Where is she?

question: She's sleeping.
answer: Let's wake her up.

question: I've seen him.
answer: Where?

question: Like, a week ago. Twice I've seen him. Watering...With the garden crews. I remember he was wearing a Liza Minnelli T-shirt. I thought that was funny.
answer: What about the others?

question: No. Just him. I remember the T- shirt. I remember thinking it was odd...?
answer: What, the Liza Minelli shirt?

question: No. I do think Liza Minelli's gone odd, but that wasn't it.
answer: What was odd?

question: He was a Saudi. The gardener.
answer: Yeah.

question: Saudis, like Americans, don't do manual labor. Blowing leaves is beneath them.
answer: Thank you.

question: How are your Sons? That's the name of a clinical psychologist. Works with Embassy kids...apparently very good at explaining violence-
answer: -what do you know about what my kids need? What they saw? What the rest of their lives might be like?

question: I thought maybe your Boys...without their Mom anymore...might ask you why sometime... I will find the man responsible for the death of your wife. We're close.
answer: Tomorrow it'll be somebody else's wife.

question: Then tomorrow I'll come back.
answer: The gardener. We know who he is. He's on several watch lists.

question: We know where he lives?
answer: We will very soon.

question: You don't seem very excited.
answer: These are always the easy ones to catch. Rarely does it lead to the planners. I want to take you somewhere.

question: Where?
answer: To someone who may be able to help us catch Hamza.

question: It was an American. An engineer named Karl Twitchell. Hired by Saudi Arabia to find water. He didn't find so much as a dried oasis, but he found this. Enough oil to turn the earth. They say my country sits on over 1 trillion more barrels of recoverable oil.
answer: A trillion reasons for our Leaders to hold hands another one hundred years.

question: A trillion reasons to keep fighting. For both sides of this War. I think our oil has begun destroying more than it creates.
answer: Agreed.

question: I'm 46 years-old. I have three daughters. And I find myself in a place where I no longer care about `why' we are attacked. I only care that 100 people woke up a few mornings ago had no idea it was their last. When we catch the Man who murdered these people, I don't care to ask even one question...I just want to kill him...stop him. Do you understand?
answer: Yes, I do. Is your first name `Colonel?'

question: At one time, Talal was Arafat's senior bomb-maker and planner in the occupied territories. He joined Bin-Laden when Al Qaeda brought the fight to the Royal Family.
answer: OK. Shouldn't we arrest him or shoot him or something?

question: He turned himself in last year during an amnesty. He's now part of a new government effort to balance the experience of Saudi Youth.
answer: This place is community service?

question: If America figures out a way of keeping their kids off the computers please let us know.
answer: Why did he turn himself in?

question: `You only come after I see there were bombs. Did you know Bin Laden put 5 million-dollars on my head? Why shouldn't it be 10?' The Man who made War on Al-Rahmah is someone my age -- this kind of skill is learned over decades. A Man who can plan the mass-murder of women and children, then go home at night to his own and sleep soundly...? That kind of Man is supremely difficult to catch.
answer: How does he know he slept soundly?

question: Because he hasn't stopped. You stop when their faces don't let you close your eyes...
answer: Is that why you quit?

question: 17 days without sleep will make you quit anything. He says he makes my job easier. Here, at least they only fight and kill on computers. He says that there are several ways to get American military equipment like this detonator but not many men in Saudi Arabia that know how to get them.
answer: How do they get them?

question: Usually smuggled from Iraq by corrupt soldiers working with the Americans.
answer: Could Hamza get this equipment?

question: Without question. Yes, he could.
answer: How do we find him?

question: Prayer. Luck. Handshakes.
answer: Well, I think I get the `prayer' and `luck' parts...

question: Whatever this is, it blasted-off like NASA.
answer: Driven in at an angle... go deeper...

question: `High-order explosion' doesn't do it justice
answer: Hospital Identification... Ambulance identification.

question: Do you know this hospital?
answer: Yes.

question: The ambulance was reported stolen from King Fahd Hospital last Wednesday, three days before the bombing. There's more
answer: What you got?

question: The stolen ambulance had a twenty man crew that rotated shifts on it. We checked all twenty men. One of them, Muaath Hazmi is now of interest to us.
answer: Why?

question: Because this gentleman is Fathi Hazmi, Muaath's brother.
answer: Where's Muaath?

question: Neighbors clear?
answer: Yes.

question: Activity or communication?
answer: Snipers have seen nothing. No telephone line into the house.

question: Allahuakbar. Go.
answer: ONE DOWN! RPG!

question: He's gone... This shrapnel look like the stuff you pulled at the morgue?
answer: Yeah... I pulled so much it's hard to remember it all.

question: Bolts?
answer: Yes.

question: Wing nuts?
answer: Yeah.

question: Razor blades?
answer: Sure.

question: Ask him. 3 vehicles will stay behind when the Prince and Press leave. You'll convoy straight to BA flights into Dulles -- last minute fares come out of your budget, by-the-by. Tried to swing upgrades, but check at the counter. Turn those frowns upside down, people. This will be pitched as a stunning Saudi-only counter-punch that killed those responsible for Al-Rahmah. Al-Jazeera will play up an FBI presence, we'll play up their ties to Terror as checkmate. And everyone that was so righteously pissed back home is gonna eat crow. Already a rumor that the guy who wrote our State Department memo-
answer: -Ellis Leach?

question: You know him? He's gonna be put out to pasture
answer: We didn't win shit, Schmidt. These are teenagers... children with pictures that someone far senior has provided them.

question: -kidding me? You mean those are Terrorist targets? Holy Wow. Momma, don't let your children grow up to be cowboys. Just get ready to go home and revel in the fact that for the next few weeks your shit won't stink. Double or nothing that's a congratulatory call.
answer: Hello? Yes, Sir. We're all here and healthy. I'm sitting next to their corpses but this may not be over. These don't feel like anything resembling senior leadership- -thank you Sir. I do. Please do me one favor before we board What do you think?
